label: axiom-projection-compatibility
name: Axiom of Projection Compatibility
statement: Projection compatibility: There exists a function $R_{\mathcal Y}:\varphi(\mathcal X)\to\mathbb R$ such that $R = R_{\mathcal Y}\circ\varphi$ on $\mathcal X$. Equivalently, if $\varphi(x)=\varphi(x')$ then $R(x)=R(x')$.
mathematical_expression: R = R_{\mathcal Y}\circ\varphi \text{ on } \mathcal X \text{, i.e., } \varphi(x)=\varphi(x') \Rightarrow R(x)=R(x')
core_assumption: The reward function must factor through the projection map from state space to algorithmic space. This ensures that the reward is determined solely by the algorithmic representation $\varphi(x)$, not by irrelevant details of the full state $x \in \mathcal{X}$. This compatibility condition guarantees that states with identical projected positions have identical rewards, making the algorithmic space a valid abstraction for optimization.

R.name: Reward Function
R.description: The reward function defined on the full state space $\mathcal{X}$.

R_Y.name: Projected Reward Function
R_Y.description: The well-defined reward function on the image of the projection map. This function encodes the reward structure in the algorithmic space, and is related to the original reward by $R = R_{\mathcal{Y}} \circ \varphi$.

varphi.name: Projection Map
varphi.description: The Lipschitz-continuous projection map from state space to algorithmic space. It extracts the algorithmically relevant features from full states.

X.name: State Space
X.description: The full state space where walkers reside. A Polish metric space $(\mathcal{X}, d_{\mathcal{X}}, \mu_{\mathcal{X}})$ with metric and reference measure.

Y.name: Algorithmic Space
Y.description: The bounded algorithmic space $\mathcal{Y} \subset \mathbb{R}^m$ equipped with Euclidean metric $d_{\mathcal{Y}}(y,y') = \|y-y'\|_2$. The space where measurement, aggregation, and standardization operations occur.

L_varphi.name: Projection Lipschitz Constant
L_varphi.description: The Lipschitz constant of the projection map: $d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(x), \varphi(x')) \le L_{\varphi} \, d_{\mathcal{X}}(x, x')$ for all $x, x' \in \mathcal{X}$.

condition: For all states $x, x' \in \mathcal{X}$, if they project to the same point in algorithmic space (i.e., $\varphi(x) = \varphi(x')$), then they must have identical rewards (i.e., $R(x) = R(x')$). This ensures $R_{\mathcal{Y}}$ is a well-defined function on the image $\varphi(\mathcal{X})$.

failure_mode_analysis.violation_description: If projection compatibility is violated, the same algorithmic state $y \in \varphi(\mathcal{X})$ could correspond to different rewards depending on which preimage $x \in \varphi^{-1}(y)$ is chosen. This makes $R_{\mathcal{Y}}$ ill-defined as a function.
consequences: The swarm cannot reliably learn from algorithmic features alone, since identical projected positions would yield inconsistent reward signals
Standardization and fitness potential calculations become meaningless, as the same algorithmic configuration could have arbitrary reward variance
The entire measurement pipeline breaks down: aggregated statistics in $\mathcal{Y}$ would not reflect consistent reward structure
Cloning decisions become unpredictable: walkers with identical algorithmic positions could have drastically different selection probabilities
Convergence analysis becomes impossible, as the algorithmic space $\mathcal{Y}$ is no longer a valid abstraction for the reward landscape
failure_mode_analysis.detection_strategy: For a random sample of state pairs $(x_1, x_2)$ satisfying $\varphi(x_1) = \varphi(x_2)$, verify that $R(x_1) = R(x_2)$ holds within the limits of numerical precision (i.e., $|R(x_1) - R(x_2)| < \varepsilon_{\text{machine}}$). If significant deviations are found, the projection map is incompatible with the reward structure.
remediation: Redesign the projection map $\varphi$ to preserve all reward-relevant features
Enrich the algorithmic space $\mathcal{Y}$ to include additional dimensions that capture reward-determining state components
If the reward genuinely depends on state features not captured by $\varphi$, redefine the reward function $R$ to factor through the current projection

framework_role: This axiom establishes the mathematical consistency between the state-space reward function and its algorithmic-space counterpart. It is a prerequisite for all downstream measurement and standardization operations, which assume that reward structure is fully determined by the projection $\varphi(x)$. The regularity of $R_{\mathcal{Y}}$ on $(\mathcal{Y}, d_{\mathcal{Y}})$ is separately guaranteed by the Axiom of Reward Regularity.
implementation_notes: In the Canonical Fragile Swarm (Euclidean case), if $\mathcal{X} = \mathcal{Y} = \mathbb{R}^d$ and $\varphi$ is the identity map, this axiom is trivially satisfied with $R_{\mathcal{Y}} = R$
For non-injective projections (e.g., dimensionality reduction, symmetry quotients), this axiom requires careful reward design to respect the projection structure

When $\varphi$ admits a Lipschitz right-inverse $\psi: \varphi(\mathcal{X}) \to \mathcal{X}$ (i.e., $\varphi \circ \psi = \text{id}_{\varphi(\mathcal{X})}$), one can relate the Lipschitz constants: $L_{R,\mathcal{Y}} \le L_R \cdot L_{\psi}$
For general projections without right-inverses, treat $L_{R,\mathcal{Y}}$ as an independent environmental parameter

special_cases.identity_projection: If $\varphi$ is the identity map (or injective), the axiom is automatically satisfied: $R_{\mathcal{Y}} = R \circ \varphi^{-1}$ on the image
special_cases.quotient_projection: If $\mathcal{X} = \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Z}$ and $\varphi$ projects onto the first factor, the axiom requires $R(y, z) = R(y, z')$ for all $z, z' \in \mathcal{Z}$
special_cases.dimensionality_reduction: For feature extraction $\varphi: \mathbb{R}^d \to \mathbb{R}^m$ with $m < d$, the reward must depend only on the extracted $m$-dimensional features
